title: Hai's departure
body:
So Hai is leaving. And while I am very sad that my probably favorite pro player is stepping down, I hope that C9 can bounce back stronger than ever from their first  roster swap r. But I am slightly worried that with Hai gone, C9 as we know it will also go. 

 And I also wish hai, who was in his prime in my opinion the best midlaner in NA, and was also hands down the best shotcaller in NA, will have success and fulfillment in his career as coach/supporting staff for C9.

I also think that Hai should get a lot of respect and not hate from the community, because Cloud9, led by hai, did so much to improve the level of play in NA. Their 25/3 record shows how much stronger they were in the summer split of 2013. And they were a major contributing factor to the growth of NA as a whole. Hai has done so much for the NA scene, just as much as the early founders of the scene, people like HotshotGG, Reggie, STVicious, and others. They were the founders, but hai was one the main leaders of NA growth as a region. 

I for one will miss watching him play very much. {{item:3070}}

replies.body: that´s a shame, would have hoped they´d try to swap him and meteos. He had been a brilliant Jungler when he first appeared on the scene (even carrying on tp-ap-jungle-yi) and it´s way easier to shoutcall as a jungler compared to sololaner in my experience (as you constantly look on the "bigger picture" anyway).
The biggest part, imo, of him leaving is his wrists. Swapping in and out with Meteos would not allow him time to heal.
Yeah he even said in the official statement that he just couldn't put in the time to improve because of his wrists and it was holding his team back

Honestly, he currently was probably the weakest link in c9. He helped develop a better NA scene but he was to inconsistent to really be considered a top mid laner. When he is doing well he carries games. when he isn't the entire team suffers.

And I as a C9 fan I like to think back to then when i think of hai, not the more recent games.

Best shot caller maybe. Bejersen has basically always been better then Hai. Also Hai was the weakest link in 2013 too. Just NA was not prepared for his really good shot calling and the amazing synergy C9 had.

Hai was definitely not a weak link during the 2013 summer and 2014 summer splits. In my honest opinion he was better than bjergsen during the spring split, both in mechanics and strategy. sad to see such an innovative player step down

I'm glad he retired.  Watching his gameplay and knowing that he's been playing injured all split made me worried about him.  Carpal Tunnel is brutal and he is a young guy still.

I wish him the best as a coach and I hope their new mid-laner works out.
He didn't become the coach. He became C9's Chief Gaming Officer (CGO) in charge of scouting new talent for all games C9 will be involved in and managing/getting new sponsors.

He win be missed greatly from the TSM organization. Lots o frespect amongst the teams, and bjerg has learned so much from hai. Hate to see him leave but,.. that wrist :(   

Farewell {{summoner:7}} HAI {{summoner:7}}

In my opinion, without hai and c9 bursting into the na scene, na would still be a shit team at international competition and only ever dream about beating any "world-class" teams. But because of cloud 9's revolutionary play, NA is actually a contender for international competitions now. I wish Hai the best of luck in the rest of his adventures and thank him for every single thing he has done for the league secene as a whole

Hai was never the best mid in NA in his prime, he was and still is the best shotcaller however.

Yes. In one of the pieces when Bjerg first came over, he said of all the mids in NA, Hai gave him the most trouble. Hai in his prime, before the injuries, was at least on Bjerg's level. The Bjerg of today is not the Bjerg  of then, same as the Hai of today is nowhere near the Hai of then. The injuries pretty much ruined Hai, but thats life. He was a very strong mid before carpal tunnel and lung issues, that obviously limits the amount of time he can put into the game.

Hai's only problem back then, wasn't mechanics, it was his champion pool, which has always been shallow.

But people seem to only remember current events. Of course the Hai of today is honestly the worst mid laner in NA. But he was nowhere near this bad before all the crap happened to him. Just like the dominating force of Bjerg today was not anywhere near what he was when he first came over. 

I think if Hai was still on his game, before all the injuries, C9 would be perfectly fine. He would be, probably #2 mid NA. Instead, hes number 10 thanks to injuries.

And, I think other posters hit another key point; Balls has been underperforming for a while now, too. The only 3 players playing at a consistently decent level is Sneaky, Meteos, and Lemonation. Esp. Sneaky and Meteos. Balls hasnt been good at all this split.
I fwe don't use stats the comparisons boil down to opinion which is not productive.
you have to put into the fact C9 went 25-3 in 2013 only team close was TSM at 14-14 LOL

You can still be worse than the other mid but still win because you have different strengths (Hai - Shotcalling) and how C9 were very good in teamplay. People are kind of overrating Hai, don't get me wrong he was GOOD, but he was never the best in any season. There is no question though that Hai is the best shotcaller NA has EVER had.

Actually, Vulcun was the only team even remotely close to C9 with a 20-8 record, backed up by being the only team to tie with a head-to-head record with C9. And it was a distinct second, as like you said TSM was the next highest after that with a 14-14 record.

As a matter of fact, both Vulcun and C9 ended the regular season with no losing head-to-head records that split. C9 only had an even win-loss record against Vulcun, and Vulcun only suffered an even win-loss record against C9, TSM, and CLG, if I remember correctly.
hotshot is a huge shitter though.

I'm upset that Hai is leaving. But he's right: he needs his wrists to heal and his confidence level looks like its going down due to that injury. I hope he gets well soon so that he can start playing competitively again without having to worry about his injury.

It's really not unexpected. He's always had a limited champion pool and recently his health has been on the decline. 

Despite that though he was a core part of C9, and I'm very curious to see how the team handles the loss of their shotcaller moving forward.

It is crazy how short a professional LoL player's career is. 

I have mad respect for Hai. Regardless of whether you think he was THE best, he will always be a champion and no one can ever take that away from him. Seems like a nice guy. I'm sad to see him go.
When you have an injury it's best to step down. No need to be upset I'm happy for him. Health comes first. Besides he's still a part of the team, he's just in a new role. Wish him the best.

Honestly, as long as the rest of the team stays together, I think that the team will be much, much better next season. Hopefully they can bring in somebody with better mechanics and have somebody on the existing roster replace him as shotcaller (Meteos maybe?). But overall, I think this will be an improvement for the team in the end.
